awd_titl_txt: Liquid-Solid Flows with Inertia and Particle Settling
awd_abstract_narration:
Flows of liquids that contain solid particles are important in a wide variety of industries, with examples that include coal slurry pipelines, hydraulic fracturing processes, and the processing of materials for energy production.  For example, the production of fuel from biomass involves grinding the biomass, then mixing it with water to create a slurry of settling, solid biomass particles that are then pumped into a reactor for further processing.  Understanding these liquid-solid slurries and how they behave in flow will enable the use of less water and energy in their processing.  Similar examples occur in the handling and storage of nuclear wastes, and in a wide range of geophysical flows including landslides and sediment transport.  This award will support unique experiments on liquid-solid flows under conditions where the inertia of both the liquid and the solid are important.  This inertial regime is important in a range of industrial problems including those above and has not been previously studied.  This research, using a custom-built instrument, will provide a set of experimental data that can be used to help predict particle settling, particle bed expansion, and the forces required to flow these slurries.  An integral part of the research is the education of students.  In addition, a series of online modules will be created to address challenges facing women in the fields of science, technology, mathematics, and engineering and how to make STEM academic and research environments more inclusive.

The goal of the proposal is to study non-colloidal particle suspensions using a custom-built rheometer, and to produce a rich experimental data set in an unexplored parameter regime of solid volume fraction and particle Reynolds number.  The apparatus generates flow between concentric cylinders, and measurements using either neutrally-buoyant or settling particles will cover particle Reynolds numbers from 0.1 to 1,400 and solid fractions from dilute to dense.  Measurements will include 1) the shear stress and the collisional particle pressure for neutrally-buoyant suspensions over a wide range of flow conditions, including turbulent suspension flows, 2) the stresses and bed expansion for conditions in which the particles are denser than the surrounding fluid, and 3) two-components of the local particle velocities, the vertical variation in solid fraction, and particle collisions. The resulting data set will serve as a valuable benchmark for simulations and models of inertial liquid-solid flows, and will provide a basis for understanding the role of particle fluctuations and the transition to turbulence in particulate flows.

por.por_cntn:
Flows and mixing of particulate materials are ubiquitous in nature and industry, including slurry pipelines, suspensions, hydraulic fracturing processes, mining and milling operations, fluidized beds, debris flows, sediment transport, and the processing and handling of materials in a powder form. Predictions of the pressure drop, the flow rate, and the mixing times rely on an understanding of the rheological properties of the materials. However, properties of multiphase flows differ considerably from that associated with a single-phase material, such as a liquid or a gas. Prior studies have focused on multiphase properties at low speeds. For example at low or creeping speeds, an effective viscosity can be estimated for a suspension, which is based on the volumetric ratio of solids in the flow to the total volume. However, as flow rates increase, the inertia of the fluid and solid phases become important and the effective solid-fraction based properties are no longer appropriate.  The research funded by this grant focused on flow beyond the creeping regime. For these higher flow rate conditions, particle-to-particle interactions may contribute to the transport and fluid turbulence may also be enhanced or diminished by the presence of the particles. The research demonstrates how the stresses increase in this inertially-dominated regime.

 

The NSF-supported work provides new experimental measurements on the rheological behavior of neutrally-buoyant and settling particles in a liquid, dry granular materials that are fluidized, and sheared granular beds. The experimental measurements, which are published in scientific journals and presented in scientific forums, are used to develop theoretical models that can predict the flow behavior. An example of a relevant multiphase flow is a debris flow, which consists of water, gravel, sand, silt and mud. Debris flow can be triggered by intense rainfall on steep mountain slopes. To develop strategies to minimize risks of debris flows, researchers need modeling tools, such as developed in this study, which provide a methodology to predict the effective transport properties. An additional component of this research looked at the effect of particle collisions on the erosion and wear of surfaces, such as occurs at a wall of a slurry pipeline. Based on the experimental measurements, the research shows the conditions, such as speed and properties of the solid particles, in which the flow could result in the wear and damage of the surface.

 

An integral part of this research work is the education of students. This grant supported the development of online materials entitled, Giving Voice, which is a series of five recorded vignettes and supporting literature that capture the challenges that disproportionately affect women in science and engineering and labs and classrooms. The modules are designed to stimulate discussion and to challenge students, faculty, and supervisors about ways that they can be more inclusive in their academic and research pursuits. The modules are also designed to effect change in the engineering and scientific communities. These modules are available to the larger public through the site webpage. This grant also provided support and research opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students.
